thread.section_title: National News -  New York Daily News
thread.title: Iran MIT scientist with no green card fears Trump will boot him
thread.title_full: Iran MIT scientist with no green card fears Trump will boot him

author: CHRISTOPHER BRENNAN
title: Iran MIT scientist with no green card fears Trump will boot him
text:
Iranian MIT scientist without green card fears he may be kicked out of Trump's America Iran MIT scientist with no green card fears Trump will boot him Iranian scientist Aboozar Tabatabai fears that he will be kicked out of the country when his visa expires in June. (Courtesy Aboozar Taba) NEW YORK DAILY NEWS Updated: Thursday, February 2, 2017, 9:38 PM 
An MIT scientist from Iran fears that he will soon be uprooted from his adopted home after President Trump’s order targeting Muslim countries. 
Aboozar Tabatabai received his doctorate in oceanography from Rutgers University last year, though his budding academic career may be derailed if he, his pregnant wife Reyhaneh and their daughter are kicked out of the country when his visa expires in late June. 
The 33-year-old told the Daily News recently started his job modeling ocean activity in Massachusetts last month, and was not sure whether Trump would follow through on his much-discussed restrictions for Muslim travelers until they became law. 
“The first night after the order I couldn’t sleep,” he said by phone from Cambridge. “I closed my eyes and saw nightmares.” 
Court order allows Iranian man to beat Trump travel ban 
Much of the attention around the "travel ban" centered around the detention of green card holders, who Trump’s administration has may be allowed back into the country after reaching the border. 
Not discussed are those on all the other types of visas such as Tabatabai, who post-student training status currently allows him to live and work in the U.S. 
Tabatabai said that the U.S. Embassy for Iran told him that it can process neither the extension he wants nor a visa for highly skilled workers visa (H1B) that his employer could try to get for him during Trump’s 90-day suspension on visa issuance. 
A State Department spokesman told the Daily News that it would not comment on the specifics of the case, but confirmed the 90-day ban and said that the order did not affect the status of anyone currently legally residing in the U.S. President Trump's order put a 90-day ban on visa issuance to Iranian nationals. (Evan Vucci/AP) 
U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services did not immediately respond to requests for clarification about how the ban applies. 
The Marine Biological Laboratory’s Dr. Joseph Vallino told the News that Tabatabai’s particular set of scientific skills and expertise are hard to find, and that most of the applicants for similar positions are from outside the U.S. 
Though his work could help increase understanding and keep people safe during disasters such as hurricanes, the father has been labeled as potentially dangerous by the Trump administration 
“Processes for Iranians have always been brutal,” Tabatabai said, noting that even his then 9-month-old daughter had to go to an in-person interview before he came to the U.S. in 2010. 
He said that his mother, preparing to come over during the summer to help with the new baby, had her visa interview cancelled two days after the executive order. 
Tabatabai is not alone when it comes to facing an uncertain future as his visa expires. 
Despite tensions between their governments since 1979, the International Institute of Education says that there were more than 12,000 students from Iran studying in the U.S. in the 2015-2016 school year, and many students apply for the additional year of training and work as Tabatabai did. Tabatabai said that his daughter has spent almost her entire life in the U.S. (Courtesy Aboozar Taba) 
There were 1,901 reported from Iraq, 1,514 from Libya, 783 from Syria, 599 from Yemen, 253 from Sudan and 35 from Somalia. 
Tabatabai said that he faces limited job options back in Iran because of his involvement with the U.S., but does not want to stay in the United States illegally when his visa expires. 
“It is a matter of dignity. I came here because I was invited here,” the scientist said, adding that he does not want to be a criminal in the country where he was once welcomed. 
Despite the hatred he feels from those Americans who would want to kick him out, he says that he wants to make the U.S., where his 7-year-old daughter Zahra has spent almost her entire life, his adopted home. 
He said that he is glad she is young enough that he does not have to explain to her why people want her to leave the place where she has g 
While the ban has been tough psychologically for many in his community, Tabatabai that he is encouraged by the support he receives from friends and colleagues on “the good half of the country” that want him to stay. 
“That’s why I like to live in this country. That ‘s why I want to live in this country,” he said. Join the Conversation:
